Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
06/27/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Erica Marshall, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
• (1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
2

• (e) Three dated references which are
obtained prior to employment from
persons unrelated to the employee and
which are less than 12 months old.
One of two new employee files did not contain three dated references as required. Only
1 of 3 references were located in the employee's file.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The facility must create and follow a clear process on how resident clothing is
documented at admission and discharge.
• Bed Check log will need to properly document 15 min intervals. Facility will revise
bed check log to take away pre-filled 15 min check points.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility should create and follow a uniform process for employee records to
ensure all the information required by licensing rules is in the employee's file,
especially at the time of the facility's annual audit. The files provided by HR were
missing some documents. It doesn't matter if the HR files come from the program
directly or HR, but the file provided should include all required documents.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
No
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility was cited during the June 5, 2024 audit for the following non-
compliances:
• CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident radio. The facility had to update
document to show that random times for bed checks were being
completed during sleeping hours every 15-minute intervals. The
development of the process for signatures was added to supervisions to
ensure that all required documents were completed and signed. The
3

revised document to monitor supervisor of youth at night helped the staff
to ensure that random times were being selected throughout the night.
• CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan (5) The social service supervisor shall
approve, countersign, and date the initial treatment plan. The facility was
cited for not having a supervisor's signature on a report. The facility
developed a CAP to ensure that documents were not filed without the
case planner/counselor, supervisor and/or director of the Shelter/TIL
Department signing the document.
• CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
Institutions; updated treatment plan. The facility was cited for an updated
service plan not having a document written by the Clinical Services
Manager countersigned by the Director of the Shelter/TIL Department.
The facility developed a CAP to ensure that documents were not filed
without the case planner/counselor, supervisor and/or director of the
Shelter/TIL Department signing the document.
The corrective action plan was completed and the facility was found in
compliance.
Financial Overview
Alternative For Girls 2025 financial budget and financial audit was reviewed. There
were no concerns noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Director of the Shelter/TIL Department reported full compliance with the
Corrective Action Plan (CAP) from the previous audit. The Director noted that there
was no impact on meeting statutory, administrative licensing rules, ISEP, policy, or
contract requirements. The facility developed a process to ensure that all
documents are signed by the assigned staff and supervisor. This signature process
was incorporated into supervision to confirm that all required documents are
completed and signed. A revised monitoring tool for overnight supervision helped
staff select random check-in times throughout the night. There were two unplanned
discharges from Alternatives For Girls. One participant was hospitalized, and
another refused to disclose her discharge destination. Her parent and the police
were contacted, and a Missing Person’s Report was filed. The Director will continue
to monitor all services provided to youth in both the short-term and treatment
programs. Weekly Case Planning Meetings are held to review youth progress and
discuss goals related to family reunification or, when appropriate, independent
living. Additionally, the Clinical Services Manager facilitates weekly team meetings
with case planners and counselors. Together, the youth, family, case planner or
counselor, and Clinical Services Manager develop a treatment plan to address
4

identified goals. The Director collaborates with the Shelter Manager and Facilities
Manager to ensure the shelter remains safe and that all youth needs are met. The
Director also works with the Clinical Services Manager to support case planners
and counselors in guiding youth and families toward successful reunification or
transition to the facility’s treatment program or other safe placements with family
members or external programs.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff shared a generally positive view of the agency’s programs and support
systems, noting recent training in trauma-informed care and Mental Health First
Aid. They highlighted efforts to improve communication with youth and emphasized
that services are most effective when parents are involved. Staff felt supported in
their roles and described leadership as open to feedback. While they cited staffing
challenges—particularly the need for more case managers—they noted hiring
efforts are in progress. The work environment was described as emotionally
rewarding, with strong staff-youth relationships creating a family-like atmosphere.
Areas identified for improvement included enhancing communication about
operational procedures and ensuring more consistent training for front desk
personnel.
Youth currently in the program reported positive experiences, feeling satisfied with
services and describing the environment as safe and supportive. They noted that
daily group sessions offer consistent opportunities for connection and engagement,
and some youth mentioned support in preparing for college or participating in
additional activities like summer camp volunteering. Youth felt their basic needs,
including food and clothing, were adequately met and said they felt comfortable
expressing their needs to staff. While overall feedback was favorable, some youth
suggested expanding the selection of television programming. In general, youth
described the shelter as a secure and welcoming space where they feel heard and
cared for.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A tour of the facility occurred during the inspection on 6/27/25. The facility was
clean and in good condition. There were no safety concerns noted during the
inspection.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
